5.text:
OK. Well, thank you very much for inviting
me and thank you all for coming.

9.text:
Now, when you look round this wonderful museum
you will see, or have seen, in various display cases

15.text:
old toy soldiers, and when you go to
the shop you will see new toy soldiers.

21.text:
And basically this talk is about British toy soldiers
- from the old toy soldiers, as in the display cases,

26.text: to the new toy soldiers, as in the shop.

31.text:
I, myself, am not a toy soldier collector
or dealer; I'm just a historian who is

37.text:
interested in toy soldiers as a 
part of our history.

41.text:
The toy soldiers I will be talking about 
are mostly the little 54mm

47.text:
- that's about two and a quarter inches - 
1:32 scale figures like this one.

52.text:
Probably those of you at the back can't see it, 
but anyway. And I hope for some of you this talk

61.text: may be a sort of trip down memory lane.

63.text:
Now, of course, the subject of toy soldiers
is not important history. It is not in any way

69.text:
as important as the history you normally
get here and it would be absurd to

74.text:
try to argue that it was. But, I suggest, 
toy soldiers are of some historical significance

81.text: and, I hope, of some interest.

83.text:
Now, if you look up there you can see the
classic image of British toy soldiers -

91.text:
say the 1930s or whatever, Highlanders, nice red
coats, glossy paint, etc, etc,

97.text:
and behind them a nice wooden fort. Unfortunately, 
the image isn't quite what it seems, because

102.text:
these are actually Chinese replicas made for collectors
fairly recently. But, as I say, it does give the image,

109.text:
which I am sure many of you remember,
of the nice glossy painted toy soldiers.

124.text:
For over 100 years from the 1880s playing
with toy soldiers was a part of British boyhood.

132.text:
In his memoirs, 'My Early Life', Winston Churchill
wrote about the toy soldiers he had as a boy in the 1880s.

139.text:
'I had ultimately nearly 1,500.
They were all of one size, all British.

148.text: The toy soldiers turned the current of my life.'

154.text:
In the same period Churchill's contemporary,
GM Trevelyan, and his brothers up north at

160.text:
Wallington Hall in Northumberland were war
gaming with 3,800 toy solders -

165.text:
that's quite a lot of toy soldiers, isn't it? 3,800. 
Trevelyan later, of course, the most famous historian

174.text:
of his generation, wrote in his autobiography that
these war games influenced his history writing

180.text:
and enabled him to describe battles. And today
Wallington Hall is owned and run by the

187.text:
National Trust, and if you go up there you can 
actually see the toy soldiers, not quite all of them,

193.text:
Moving on. In the Edwardian period one of
the boys who played with toy soldiers was

198.text:
Basil Hart, later famous as Captain Sir Basil
Liddell-Hart, the controversial military pundit

206.text:
and historian. Liddell-Hart wrote in his memoirs
that 'when playing with lead soldiers I like

213.text:
to make the game as tactical as possible.
Manoeuvring them rather than arranging them

222.text:
Other memoirs and autobiographies also tell
of boys playing with their toy soldiers.

228.text:
You will find this in the memoirs or autobiographies
of Dennis Wheatley, of Graham Greene,

234.text:
of AJP Taylor and others. And this also occurs in
fiction, in the books by HG Wells, by E Nesbitt,

241.text:
by Saki, by Richmal Crompton, by Evelyn Waugh,
by Kingsley Amis and others. And more recently

248.text:
those who played with toy soldiers include
His Royal Highness, Prince Charles,

253.text:
Sir Max Hastings, Roy Hattersley, Clive James and
Professor Sir Hew Strachan, Chichele Professor

262.text:
of the History of War at Oxford University
and formerly a trustee of this museum.

269.text:
So all the evidence indicates that playing with
toy soldiers was very widespread and normal

277.text:
Yet, of course, there were always exceptions.
Some boys just weren't interested and some

283.text:
parents would not allow their children to
have 'war toys' and that was obviously true

289.text:
with Quakers and other pacifists. In fact
war toys were a continued, if relatively minor,

296.text:
concern of the peace movement. For example,
in March 1914 - ie before the First World War -

303.text:
the National Peace Council, which was
a sort of umbrella organisation of pacifist

309.text:
organisations, stated their 'grave objection
to toy soldiers'. And at the Child's Welfare Exhibition

317.text: at Olympia they put on a display of 'peace toys',

323.text:
with 'not miniature soldiers but miniature civilians... 
not guns but ploughs and the tools of industry'.

329.text:
Next, let's look at the history of toy solders
and a little bit about what's been written

336.text:
and published on them. Now, today, there's
a lot available... in fact if you go down

341.text:
the shops you can see some of it, there's
a lot available on toy soldiers.

346.text:
And today the books, the articles and the websites on
toy soldiers are almost all by hobbyists,

353.text:
collectors, dealers and experts from the flourishing
international toy soldier collector community.

362.text:
Today, old toy soldiers, like old teddy bears,
are very collectable, though incidentally

368.text:
they are much cheaper than teddy bears - 
the big money is in teddy bears, that's just by

373.text:
the way. Just to give you an example and a
slight digression, a 1904 cinnamon-colour

378.text:
Steiff teddy bear called 'Teddy Girl' sold
at Christies for £110,000. No toy soldiers

385.text: have ever sold for anything like that.

388.text:
Now, today, among the people who write on
toy soldiers, the leading expert on British

394.text:
toy soldiers, the author of standard books,
is Mr James Opie. He is himself an enthusiastic

402.text:
collector and over the years he accumulated
about 65,000 figures, then he had to move

407.text:
house so he slimmed down his collection to
about 16,000. And Mr Opie has made an entire

415.text:
successful career as a toy soldier expert,
writing books and working for the leading

421.text: auction houses - Phillips, Christies and Bonhams.

425.text:
Another writer on toy soldiers, and in fact
really the odd one out because he is an academic

429.text:
historian, is Professor Kenneth Brown, who
is Professor Emeritus at Queens University, Belfast.

436.text:
He is actually an economic historian.
He has written books on the history of the

440.text:
toy industry, quite a depressing subject actually,
and articles on toy soldiers in learned and

447.text:
academic journals. And in this lecture I draw
with gratitude on the publications of Mr James Opie,

457.text:
OK. Let's look briefly at the history and
the background of toy soldiers. The early

463.text:
history of toy soldiers can be traced back for centuries 
in different countries and different cultures.

468.text:
They are made in varied sizes and materials, 
in silver for princes and in wood

474.text: or metal for lesser mortals like us.

477.text:
Now, in the 1880s, which is where we're really
starting in this talk, in the 1880s there

484.text:
was no, or no significant manufacture of toy
soldiers in Britain. Toy soldiers just weren't

491.text:
made here. There may have been the old wooden
toy soldier but basically what we know of

496.text:
as toy soldiers just weren't made in this
country. Toy soldiers were imported;

499.text:
they were imported from Germany and France, and
mostly from Germany. And Winston Churchill's

506.text:
and GM Trevelyan's toy soldiers were in fact
made in Germany.

512.text:
In the late 19th and early 20th century Germany
was the world's leading toy manufacturer and exporter.

518.text:
In Edwardian England about half
the toys sold were actually German imports.

525.text:
The leading German toy soldier manufacturer
was Heyde of Dresden. And Heyde, and other

531.text:
German toy soldiers, were solid metal figures
and relatively expensive. This point about

537.text:
them being solid is quite significant, as
you will see in a moment.

541.text:
And this brings us to the biggest name in
British toy soldier history, the firm of Britains -

548.text:
I am sure, many of you, if not most of you,
have heard of Britains.

552.text:
Now, Britains was a London family firm. It
was started by William Britain Sr;

559.text:
his dates are 1831-1907. If you're interested you can
look online on the Dictionary of National Biography

566.text:
and there's an article there about
William Britain and his family.

571.text:
Now, William Britain Sr was a skilled metalworker.
He was a brass worker and he came from Birmingham,

578.text:
which of course was a great metalworking centre.
He moved to London, he married a London girl

583.text:
and he had a large family - they had five
sons and four daughters.

588.text:
And probably from the 1860s, nobody seems
to know quite for sure, William Britain Sr

594.text:
started manufacturing toys. But the toys he
manufactured were quite large clockwork toys

600.text:
and other mechanical toys. He made a waltzing
cowboy, a tea drinking mandarin, all clever

606.text:
little mechanical toys, and these were made
at the Britains' family home which was in

613.text:
Islington. And I think what one needs to emphasise
was it was on a very small scale, it was a

617.text:
workshop production, craftsman production,
it wasn't a factory at all, it was very small scale.

623.text:
Then in 1893 - a key date in our story - in
1893 William Britain Jr, who was a son of

630.text:
William Britain Sr - William Britain Jr, whose
dates are 1859-1933, made a crucial innovation

638.text:
which transformed the fortunes of the Britains'
family firm and also transformed the manufacture

645.text:
of toy soldiers. William Britain, as I am
sure many of you already know, introduced

651.text:
hollow casting. Now, the method of casting
might seem a mere nerdish technicality,

661.text: but in fact it made a crucial difference.

663.text:
Now, hollow casting itself was not new, it
had been used for various things including

667.text:
dolls heads, but its application to the manufacture
of metal toy soldiers was 'new and revolutionary' -

675.text:
that's James Opie's term for it, 'new and
revolutionary'. Now, in hollow casting molten metal,

681.text:
a lead alloy, was poured into a handheld
brass mould and then it ran out and it left

690.text:
a hollow figure. Now, in theory it is very simple. 
In practice, it is rather more difficult to do.

697.text:
In other words, the production of these toy
soldiers was not by machines, it was by craftsmen.

702.text:
It was a whole load of individual craftsmen
each with their handheld brass mould and ladle

708.text:
of molten metal etc, etc. And these individual
craftsmen, skilled craftsmen, could do over

715.text:
300 figures per hour - quite a lot - 300 figures
per hour. After the castings had been made,

722.text:
they were then painted by women in the factory.
Later on they used outworkers but in the early

727.text: period the women were all in the factory.

730.text:
Now, hollow casting obviously used much less
metal than solid casting and therefore the

738.text:
hollow cast figures obviously cost much less
to produce. And, therefore, obviously they

743.text:
could be sold at much lower prices than the
imported German solid figures. And before

751.text:
the First World War they sold at very roughly
half the price of the German figures.

756.text:
Moreover, Britains soldiers were attractive.
They were well modelled, they were well painted

762.text:
and they were usually accurate - there are
odd sort of slip-ups where they got things

767.text:
wrong, but on the whole they were pretty accurate
- and they were in a standard scale,

771.text:
which we've already mentioned 1:32 scale, 54mm,
like this chap here. This scale in fact was

781.text:
the scale of the then popular Gauge One model
railways, which is quite large by modern standards.

789.text:
Now, Britains' first set came out in 1893.
It was a box of lifeguards, four troopers

795.text:
and an officer, and over the following years
this set was followed by an extensive range of sets,

803.text:
more and more and more, year after
year. There were British, there were Indian,

808.text:
there were colonial and foreign, there were
Arabs and Zulus, there were cowboys and Indians -

812.text:
cowboys and Indians very popular and very
much a part of British boyhood for a long time,

816.text:
including when I was young. I mean I
had a wooden tomahawk, but that's by the way.

823.text:
The British Army sets included a variety of
units including, of course, the Household troops,

829.text:
line infantry, Highlanders and Mountain
Artillery and the Royal Army Medical Corps.

836.text:
The Royal Army Medical Corps came complete
with ambulances, nurses, stretcher bearers

841.text:
and recumbent bandaged wounded. Usually the
bandage consisted of a rather tasteful bandage

846.text:
around the head with just a little bit of
red on it, but never corpses. Britians,

852.text:
and other British toy soldiers manufacturers,
never made dead soldiers.

858.text:
Britains also, of course, also manufactured
toy artillery guns which fired projectiles

862.text:
and caps. These were in various sizes, ranging
up to the big so-called 18-inch Howitzer,

870.text:
which I'm told fired a lead projectile with
significant force. I've never actually seen

874.text:
one fired. In fact today, when they are offered
for sale in online auctions, it says specifically

881.text:
they are not for sale to children. Things
have changed, of course. Mind you in this

885.text:
period children could actually buy guns. I
mean anybody could buy a gun. There's a Kipling

891.text:
story where these children go out and buy
a revolver. Anyway, that's by the way.

896.text:
So, Britains also manufactured vehicles, wagons,
carts, etc, and Britains were remarkably successful.

905.text:
They ousted foreign imports, they dominated
the home market and they became the world's

912.text:
leading toy soldier manufacturer. And they
retained their leading position until at least

919.text:
the end of hollow cast toy soldier production
in 1966, and arguably even after that,

929.text:
Britains exported to the empire, they exported
to the United States, despite the fact that

934.text:
the United States had high protective tariffs,
they exported to South America - in Argentina

940.text:
they were very popular, in fact in Argentina
the locals actually made their own imitations

946.text:
of Britains toy soldiers - and they even exported
to Germany. They produced very large numbers

952.text:
by 1910, about 200,000 per week - that's from
Professor Brown that figure - and according

958.text:
to James Opie the total hollow cast production
- that's from 1893 through to 1966 - was about

966.text: 1,000 million, and that is a lot.

971.text:
Now, let's look briefly at prices - just quickly.
Britains best quality models were sold in

978.text:
boxed sets. They were dark red cardboard boxes
with attractive labels and from 1893 to 1914

987.text:
a box of eight infantry or five cavalry cost
a shilling or less at Gamages -

993.text: I will mention about Gamages in a moment.

995.text:
In 1933 a box cost one shilling and seven
pence halfpenny, and there were of course

1000.text:
also much cheaper ranges. Also, Britains soon
had competitors - rival manufacturers of hollow

1009.text:
cast toy soldiers; some of them people who
had actually learnt about it by working as

1015.text:
Britains employees and then sort of slipped
away and started up their own firm. And these

1021.text:
rival firms, including Raker, BMC, Johillco,
otherwise known as John Hill & Co - and that

1028.text:
was Britains' main rival; Johillco went right
from the 1890s through to the 1960s -

1034.text:
and later, of course, Cress, Timpo and others.
These produced figures as cheap or cheaper

1040.text:
than Britains and presumably competition kept
prices down.

1045.text:
Now, let's look at availability and retail.
Toy soldiers were widely available in various

1052.text:
retail outlets, including department stores
and notably Gamages of Holborn - there's Gamages

1060.text: in all its glory. That's from their 1913 catalogue.

1065.text:
Now, some of you may remember Gamages. It
closed in 1972. It was demolished and there's

1073.text:
absolutely no sign of it left. Nothing at all. 
But it had been started back in 1878,

1078.text:
started on a very small scale - it was just
a small shop - by the enterprising Mr Albert

1083.text:
Gammage, and it grew and grew and grew. From
this one small shop he kept taking more and

1089.text:
more adjoining premises until it ends up like
that. And by the 1890s it was a leading London

1099.text:
department store known as 'the people's popular
emporium'. It was much advertised and had

1105.text: a flourishing catalogue and mail order business.

1109.text:
Now, unlike other department stores, Gamages
focused very much on men rather than on ladies

1117.text:
and it specialised in sports equipment, sports
clothes, etc. It was quite a masculine place

1123.text:
in its early days. Gamages sold an amazing
range of goods, including motor cars, billiard tables,

1131.text:
12-bore shot guns and live alligators,
and is also had a big and famous toy department.

1140.text:
In 1893, in other words when Britains started,
Mr Gammage agreed to sell Britains toy soldiers

1148.text:
and his store effectively became the launch
pad for Britains toy soldiers. In fact Gamages

1157.text:
displayed so many Britains soldiers that they
became known, at least according to their

1162.text:
own publicity, as 'the Aldershot of the toy
soldier world'.

1169.text:
Britains toy soldiers were also sold in Woolworths - 
Woolworths, of course, an American firm,

1174.text:
but in the UK from 1909, and by 1931 they
had 444 branches. I'm sure most of you,

1182.text:
like me, can remember the time when wherever you
seemed to go in England, whatever town

1186.text: you landed up in, there would be a Woolworths.

1189.text:
So Britains soldiers, and other toy soldiers
as well of course, were very widely available.

1195.text:
They were attractive, they were affordable
and, as I say, widely available. And, arguably,

1201.text:
supply had created demand - the fact that
these were available made people want them.

1207.text:
They also fitted what one might call the dominant
image of war, especially before 1914 -

1213.text:
the rather glamourised romantic image of war put
across in the media including The Illustrated London News,

1220.text:
The Graphic, The Navy and Army
Illustrated, and in fiction such as the works

1226.text:
of GA Henty, and in displays such the Royal
Tournament and, later on, the Aldershot Tattoo.

1233.text:
OK. Let's look now a bit more at Britains and their 
toy soldiers. Now, after their initial success,

1239.text:
their production was for many years
a mixture of continuity and innovation.

1246.text:
First of all the continuity. They continued throughout
to produce such firm favourites as the Household troops,

1253.text:
the Royal Horse Artillery, Drums and
Bugles of the Line, Highlanders and Mountain

1258.text:
Artillery. These sets went on for years and
years and years and some of them were being

1262.text:
made in the early 1960s. They had a very long
shelf life as it were.

1266.text:
Yet Britains also, especially in the early years, 
responded to current events, to contemporary

1272.text:
wars by issuing topical sets. In 1896 following
the Jameson Raid into the Transvaal,

1283.text:
which was an absolute disaster as I'm sure you will
all know, Britains issued their set,

1288.text:
'Dr Jameson and the South African Mounted Infantry', 
with Dr Jameson leading his troops into imprisonment

1295.text: in fact, but that's by the way.

1297.text:
Now, in 1898 they responded to the Spanish-American
War in Cuba by issuing sets of American and

1303.text:
Spanish troops. In 1898 also, following the
famous charge of the 21st Lancers of Omdurman,

1311.text:
Britains issued a set of '21st Lancers: Heroes
of Omdurman' in khaki foreign service uniforms.

1317.text:
During the Boer War Britains issued various
Boer War troops, including both Boers and British

1323.text:
and including the famous City Imperial
Volunteers (CIV) and the Imperial Yeomanry

1332.text:
and the famous 4.7 naval gun on its land mounting.
The point about this is that they were manufacturing

1345.text: an enormous range of sets by this date.

1350.text:
There we have some more from Gamages' 1913
catalogue. Notice here you have got

1362.text:
the Egyptian Camel Corps there, you have got the 
Royal Army Medical Corps there, Red Indians at the top,

1371.text:
sailors there. And this, of course, the
interesting set, that's the Mountain Artillery.

1377.text:
That set was very popular. It came in in the
1890s and it was still in production in the 1960s.

1382.text:
A very nice little set, and what you've got, 
for anybody who isn't familiar with it,

1386.text:
are four mules and a gun which you disassemble,
you can take it apart, and each part of the

1394.text:
gun goes on one mule. So you've got three
parts of the gun going on three mules and

1400.text:
then the fourth mule has the ammunition and
a mounted officer. Not quite an accurate model

1408.text:
because the real ones disassembled into more
parts than three. But, anyway, a nice set.

1415.text:
OK. Here we have some more again from Gamages'
1913 catalogue. Mostly Britains on this page

1422.text:
but not entirely. Notice at this date they
are making a lot of stuff to go with their

1428.text:
toy soldiers. There's guns, there's transport,
there's tents, etc, etc. And what you've got

1434.text:
- you can see the tents up there, obviously
- what you've got there is an interesting

1440.text:
set because the set was a set that comprised
Britains figures but the set was actually

1446.text:
put together by another firm and marketed
by them.

1450.text:
There you have the... what it says is 
Army Service Corp Transport. What that is, of course,

1455.text:
is the old general service wagon - the GS
wagon. And the GS wagon was the basic transport

1461.text:
of the British Army for a very long time,
right from the 1860s through to mechanisation

1466.text:
between the wars. And I am sure you have all
seen photographs of the First World War with

1471.text:
GS wagons heavily laden with stuff, often
going through the mud, etc. Therewe are,

1477.text: there is the general service wagon, the GS wagon.

1482.text:
Boy Scouts there. As I say they did make some
civilians. The Boy Scouts started in 1908.

1487.text:
A lot of media interest in it. A lot of interest
from boys, as well, of course. Naval landing

1492.text:
party with a gun there. More Boy Scouts there.
More cavalry. That's the 21st Lancers,

1500.text:
yet again, and then that's advertising one of
their big expensive sets there.

1509.text:
OK. Moving on, then. Now, during the First
World War, Britains started to make munitions,

1519.text:
but surprisingly they continued to make toy
soldiers quite late. You may remember the

1525.text:
slogan 'Business As Usual', which was used
at the early stages of the war. And in fact

1532.text:
they continued their toy soldier production
in the First World War up to 1916 and they

1537.text:
introduced some specifically First World War
models, including machine gunners, and they

1545.text:
put their 21st Lancers into steel helmets,
and they produced their biggest gun so far,

1553.text:
the so-called 18-inch Howitzer, which I've
already mentioned. They also, by the way,

1558.text:
introduced an exploding trench, but there
were such protests over this that

1564.text: they quickly withdrew it, so it's quite rare.

1568.text:
OK. Moving on to the interwar period. In the
1920s and 1930s Britains continued to manufacture

1575.text:
their pre-war and wartime sets. So, basically,
they have an enormous range and this range

1579.text:
keeps growing because they do drop a very
few but not many. And they introduced the

1587.text:
Royal Air Force, the Royal Engineers pontoons,
King's African Rifles and Royal Artillery gunners in khaki,

1595.text:
and they belatedly modernised
their field guns. Right up to this period

1601.text:
they had still been using the old Victorian-style
field guns.

1605.text:
Topical again, in 1936 at the time of the
controversial Abyssinian War they made models

1612.text:
of both Abyssinian and Italian troops. Later
in the 1930s at the time of rearmament they

1618.text:
made ARP [Air Raid Precautions] figures and
in 1940 they actually made the Home Guard.

1622.text:
That was one of the last figures they made
before they stopped production.

1629.text:
Now, in 1941 Britains switched entirely to
munitions productions - they totally stopped

1635.text:
making toy soldiers for the duration. 
And this was basically the end of an era.

1642.text:
It was the end of their huge pre-war range, which
you have seen some of there. It was the end

1648.text:
of the Boer War sets, the 17th Lancers, the
21st Lancers, the Yeomanry, the Pontoons,

1655.text:
the Royal Field Artillery gun teams and many
more.

1659.text:
After the Second World War, Britains resumed
toy soldier production successfully, but with

1665.text:
far fewer sets than before the war. They re-issued
some pre-war sets and they introduced a few

1671.text:
new models, including more soldiers in battle
dress. However, and this I find slightly strange,

1679.text:
in their post-war hollow cast production Britains
ignored the Second World War. They didn't

1683.text:
do the 8th Army; they didn't do any of the
specifically Second World War troops.

1689.text: Why this is I don't know.

1691.text:
Now, after the Second World War British toy
soldier production was very largely exported

1697.text:
especially to the United States. As you know
the British economy was in a bad way at that

1702.text:
time and the British government was desperate
for dollars and both Britains and their rival,

1708.text:
Johillco, were significant dollar earners.
In fact post-war about 70 per cent of Johillco

1714.text:
production was exported to the United States.
I'm afraid I don't have figures for Britains,

1719.text: my guess is it could be about the same.

1723.text:
Then, moving on, in the 1950s and 1960s came
a big change, the switch to plastic.

1731.text:
Gradually Britains made more and more plastic, 
fewer and fewer metal, and in 1966 the end of hollow

1738.text:
cast metal toy soldier production by Britains.
It was the end of an era, obviously, and the

1744.text:
era which it started, as we have seen, back
in 1893 with William Britain Jr.

1749.text:
